Also, liked to cause issues between the team and had nothing good to say about anyone. Made it uncomfortable for employees because Management liked gossiping with employees about other team members. 

After experiencing the leadership style at Anthem twice, I realized it was time to look elsewhere. It's sad because they are a great company with so much to offer.

cons:
The commercial side of things is very unorganized and can be discouraging. 

Overall there are limited opportunities for growth if you haven’t been at the company for a long time. They will give you more work and train you on new things but won’t increase your pay/title.

job_title: Utilization Management in New York, NY
pros:
Some departments let you work from home, either as hybrid or fulltime home. 

Modest raises each year 

Modest bonuses each year 

Great coworkers
cons:
Most positions at Anthem BCBS are salaried. This in itself would not be a problem, but Anthem expects you to pull 50-60 hour weeks all the time (not just during a busy season). Whenever someone quits, they refuse to hire a new nurse (they claim it's no longer in the budget, even though it was in the budget to pay this nurse before they quit) and will expect the remaining workers to absorb all the work. It doesn't matter if you're stuck working until midnight. 

If you try to tell management that you're burned out, or have to log off for a few minutes at 7pm to cook for your family before logging back on until midnight, they will tell you that you're being paid to do a job and it needs to get done. It doesn't matter that you've been working since 8am, you cannot take a few minutes to tend to your family 12 hours later. You better have a good reason for logging off for a bit. 

You can work 60 hour weeks all the time and get most of your work done, but if you dare to miss one case (because you're just burned out), you will have to send an email to the manager/director telling them why you missed turn around time on this one case and what steps you're taking to ensure it won't happen again. Really? How about recognizing that your workers are actual humans who need a break. No one is perfect and everyone makes mistakes or misses something. 

You can do 1,000 cases on time, but that one case you missed will be held against you during raise/bonus time. If you dare to take 15 minutes outside of your 30 minute lunch break to give your eyes/brain a rest from the constant work, the manager will IM you "hi" and see how long it takes you to respond. He/she will then IM you and ask where were you, why were you away from your computer. This has happened multiple times to me and many of my coworkers. I didn't know I had to ask permission to rest my tired eyes for a minute. 

Some departments are trying to make workers come back in the office. This is just a power grab on their end since the work can be done 100% from home. Also, covid isn't over yet just because Anthem's higher ups want it to be. Some people need to work from home for their health/safety. If one person isn't working up to standard, make them come in. Why punish everyone? 

For the past 4 years, the director would not allow managers to give employees "exceeds expectations" on the annual review. Any manager that gave that score was forced to change it. The director said that we will all stop working hard if we have nothing to strive for. Nothing is good enough for the directors. 

If you are an efficient worker, you will be punished with more work of those who do not work as quickly as you. The slackers are allowed to do bare minimum, as long as they are overly friendly to the directors and managers. If you are an efficient worker then have a less productive day, you will be questioned endlessly on why you had one bad day. You will never be rewarded for being productive and slackers will never be reprimanded for not being productive. I actually slowed down so I would not have everyone's work dumped on me. They won't give you interesting projects as a reward for efficient work. 

Everyone gets the same raise. If you do great work, you will get the same raise as the slacker. Also, the company will add more work to you so that your raise still averages out to like $20/hr (if you break down the salary into hourly). We felt we did not get paid fairly for all the work that kept getting piled on year after year after year.  They would lay off entire departments then just add the work to the already overworked remaining staff. 

The office built a recreation room for the upper management. It's like a lounge with a pool table and other fun things. That must have cost as much as hiring 4 or 5 new staff to help us with the overwhelming work. The regular workers are not allowed to use it. 

They are now mandating people to work holidays when this wasn't part of the job ever before. At first, they asked for volunteers and would give you a day off during the week. Now they are just rotating the holidays. This was supposed to be a no weekend/no holiday job. 

If the supportive staff make a mistake, it is the nurse's fault. You will be held responsible if one of the supportive staff forget to send a case for denial or if they forget to set up an auth shell for you. We are not their managers but we are held responsible for their work. They are adults and their manager should be managing them, not blaming the nurses. We have our own never ending work to do. If I forget to do my work, I'm blamed (rightfully so), and if the UM rep forgets to do their work, I'm blamed for that too. It's just not fair. 

If the doctor misspells something in the denial letter, or doesn't deny a case on time, the nurse is at fault (by the manager, not the doctor). We are held responsible for making sure the doctors do their jobs, in addition to doing our job and unofficially supervising the supportive staff. Doctors are higher up than us, why are we responsible for their work? Even the doctors tried to push back against this unreasonable expectation but were overruled.

job_title: Consumer Service Associate in Roanoke, VA
pros: The pay, benefits, and PTO are good
cons: I worked for DBG (Diversified Business Group), which is a subsidiary of Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield who handles some of their more complicated, "elevated", clients through customer service. I'm sure Anthem is a great place to work with, but DBG itself is severely disorganized. We were never sure we were giving our members correct information because it always changed day to day. We were advised of changes that would improve our services, which always only worsened. We were given the chance to discuss our woes with management, but when bringing up valid concerns, their only job was to tell us how well the program was organized instead of actually listening to our suggestions on how to improve. I don't care how good the pay is, I would never work there again. There's a reason they pay you more than most other customer service positions and it's because they can barely get anyone to stay there long enough due to the disorganization and lack of care for their employees. Not only do they fire people at least once a week in a small department (sometimes several times a week), but they have plenty of people quitting very often as well because of the poor treatment. They continuously try to convince employees that they will hire more people (this happened over many many months), and they do, but it's never enough to make up for the people who have been fired and who have quit.

job_title: Customer Service Representative III in Middletown, NY
pros: There are frequent openings for new hires. They provide training on the programs used. Great co-workers. A variety of work hours available as well as work from home opportunities for some positions.The starting pay is higher than most entry level positions.
cons:
There are frequent layoffs of seasoned employees, and then they hire new inexperienced replacements, many with little to no work ethic.The training given is necessary, as they are always changing systems. For current employees, you have little to know time to learn the "new", as everything you do is timed and scheduled.
They say they have a great work life balance, however, anytime you need time off or a variation in schedule, due to illness or a family situation, you are given a warnings and then inevitably fired. 
Supervisors and management have their favorites, which allows for less opportunity for advancement. 
They are a health insurance company that offers their employees the least appealing policies at a very high price.
You are encouraged to be caring to the members, which can require more time and a lot of follow up. Then you are disciplined for not being fast enough or ready for the next caller. They talk of quality, but are really all about quantity.

job_title: Customer Care Representative in Fond du Lac, WI
pros: i like some of my coworkers, and have an excellent manager.  There are onsite food vendors daily, at your own cost.
cons: The pay is off the charts low for call center work in the area. They tell you to take time on your calls, as we deal with older folks, but then hound you to bring your average handle time down.  You can't have it both ways, Anthem. When offered full-time employment, I found out that you will have to take a significant, $2 per hour pay cut due to their awesome benefits. Benefits are so not awesome. For an insurance carrier that has their own coverage for their employees, the coverage is shockingly awful. Super high deductibles, than only 80% coverage if you manage to cover your deductible is beyond ridiculous. The lower tiers of plans pay 70% and 60%, also after a large deductible. With a huge pay cut, and the cost of the insurance, plus the high deductible and coinsurance, what is the motivation to have a long term career there?  Turnover, even with long tenured employees, is quite high, even for a call center. Also, be prepared to do non call center work for no additional pay. The bonus structure is a joke, with quarterly bonuses around $100. The building is old and falling apart, and quite filthy. Due to Anthem's so called business needs, they will not approve you for PTO on Mondays. Ever.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Work from home 
Schedule is ok
cons: EVERYTHING ELSE! Impossible to get assistance or the tools you need to complete your job functions. Management and the company clearly do not care about their employees. Insurance benefits are horrible and expensive!

pros: The work is very specialized and very basic.  If you have a brain you'll be able to do a full day's work in 4 hours and goof off the rest of the time. It's a typical Office Space-style environment, and management rewards Lumbergh types by making them team leads. They know the systems well, but they're otherwise very dumb and self-serious, so they're fun to mock. If you massage their egos every once in a while, they'll leave you alone.  There's no real upward mobility and the pay is below the going market rate, but if you need to kill time while you're looking for a real job, you could do worse.
cons: You're micromanaged like crazy, and the rules are punitive. Even mid-level employees are penalized for showing up 2 minutes late for a shift. The strategies that are cooked up by upper-level management are incoherent and higher-ups refuse to change course if a scheme isn't working. Continuous reorgs and frequent mandatory overtime. There's very little room for advancement, but again, this isn't the type of place that you'd want to stay long-term anyway.

pros: I enjoyed working there. The people were great.
cons: I don't really have any cons.

pros: Pay is decent, teamwork is good, work at home sometimes

pros: Friendly co-workers, management is always doing events, plenty of overtime during peak month's (if that's your thing), lots of opportunities for advancement, decent schedules once you put in the time, bonus potential.

Training is sub-par and feels thrown together last minute.  I wont go into much detail but this was a big deal for me, they tell you that you wont retain but maybe 20% of what you learned but the real case is that most of your learning is going to be on the floor with people on the line who expect you to do and know your job.  There's a hotline for you to call for assistance but it feels like a lot of the time you are an inconvenience to them for calling to ask for help.  

There are a ton of applications that are used, each with separate passwords that are constantly asking you to change them and wont allow you to use any previous iteration of the passwords you have chosen.  This is small, and they have done a decent job at integrating most programs into one, but sometimes the system is down or slow so you better remember those passwords!

pros: Good benefits and competitive employee pay

pros: thorough training; no weekends; some managers

review_title: Apparently Not As Valuable As They Say We Are
pros: The ability to work remotely is huge and one of the few reasons I stay.  The annual bonuses are usually decent but have trailed off quite a bit recently.  In spite of what people say about health insurance companies management does seem to really want to do what's in the best interest of the members.
cons: Every single meeting we hear about how valuable we are as employees and how we're the reason the company is strong.  However, wage grow has been nearly non-existent for quite a few years.  During the downturn I understood wage growth would slow down.  However, the company is strong and the corporate tax cuts have infused a tremendous amount of money.  My last several reviews have been stellar yet according to my manager they have such a limited amount of funds available that they don't have much to give out in the way of raises.  So they pay lip service but when it really comes down to showing how valuable we are they don't put their money where their mouth is.

review_title: Overworked and Underpaid. Unnecessary stress for the amount of money being made.
pros: PTO, Holiday Pay, and quarterly incentives.
cons: Schedules change each quarter and if you don't meet certain goals you may get stuck with the shifts nobody wants. Also depending on which unit you are in management may suck. For my unit in particular, the management did not know their roles nor did they have the same understanding of many of the policies. The supervisors expected the customer service reps to know absolutely everything, you had to practically beg a supervisor to take an irate call. ALL of the meetings and 15 min huddles we had ALWAYS addressed the same issues. There wasn't a good consistent leadership.

pros: My salary is excellent and Anthem does offer many great benefits such as work from home, ability to make up time, free higher education through College of America, and amount of vacation days.
cons: The maternity policy at Anthem is not good. 6 weeks for regular birth or C-section. The first week must use vacation days. It's not full pay and I didn't get a paycheck until I came back to work because HR wouldn't work with my doctors office. It by far was the worst experience I've ever had working for a company, the struggle to get HR to acknowledge receipt of paperwork that my doctors office sent repeatedly every day for weeks to them. Many companies are now updating their maternity benefits and I feel Anthem needs to update theirs to be competitive in the corporate world.

review_title: Anthem provides a great stepping stone into the insurance industry but beware of outsourcing and poor management.

Above-average compensation

Excellent training staff
cons:

pros: They offer telecommuting and decent pay.  Quarterly and annual bonuses are available.  The savings plan is OK.  The work is interesting and my peers are easy to work with.
cons: Management consistently pushes for more work than is possible with available resources.  They cut resources and then wonder why their ever increasing demands are not met.  Work is assigned without regard for existing work load.  They do not appreciate the hard work.  The harder you work, the more work they give you.  They are horribly understaffed and the executive leadership team seems to have no clue how close their employees are to total collapse.

review_title: Doesn't Value Employees and Not Family Friendly
pros: This is a very well organized company that provides excellent training and physical work environment. Industry leader and a stable company
cons: Doesn't value hard working employees. All about the bottom line. Position was offered as telecommute after training but this was rescinded after 3 months of being promised the transition. Managers would not even negotiate this despite exceptional performance results. Time off is poorly accrued for new hires. Doesn't begin accruing until after first full month of employment. So if you start on Jan. 5, time off doesn't even begin to accrue until March 1. So you may be able to accrue at best 1 or 2 days after being there 3 or 4 months. Wouldn't allow me to take 3 days off even without pay and with my offering to work weekends to make up the time to seek medical care for my child facing life-threatening illness.  Work load was unmanageable due to high turnover in department because of how people are treated. Management is arrogant.

pros: work from home, work/life balance
cons: ever since they had that cyber attack last January 2015, the salaries for positions posted have been lower they prior years. The merit raises and bonuses have been much lower as well.

review_title: Good job with stability, decent benefits and consistent schedule

pros: The benefits are pretty good and it is dependable.  Plenty of opportunities to learn more and take on new responsibilities if you are a self starter.
cons: Training is conducted by trainers paid to teach jobs that they have never done in some cases.  Very few training opportunities after new hire training. job_title: Membership Representative in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: Big company that is not likely to go out of business
cons: This company charts how quickly a human body can do each and every minute task it takes to do any of their jobs.  It has done so for at least 30 years.  Over the years they have reduced the required time for each task in order to get more production out of the human assets for less time.  So, these days one has to be near Tom Cruz's professional level in the movie Mission Impossible to meet production standards.  You run very fast there from the time you get in the door, until the time you leave.  Many of my co-workers did not take breaks, and/or only ate at their desks for a few minutes, not taking a full lunch break ever.

pros: Working at home is by far Anthem Blue Cross' best benefit. Truly,it's the only benefit. They used to be a much better company to work for.

They state that they encourage you to ask for help but if you call researchers  because you need help ,they frown upon that ,The "Operation Experts" are basically just watch dogs,they look for things to complain about,it's a very "click-ish" attitude the managers and OE's have,

pros: Benefits are decent, location convenient right off of the highway,and the  building is  modern. Training is very through and lasts about 12 weeks. Trainer was very helpful and explained things very well, and was approachable when you had a question.

Most reviews of your performance are done out in the open.Managers are not always respectful to employees. Approval for time off/work life balance is at manager discretion and is not equal for everyone.

pros: It was a great company to work for. Had a culture of innovation and absolutely taking care of the customer. cons: Early on in the tenure, they have a strict time schedule, which is good early on but after some time, you need to trust your staff will put in the work/hours regardless if they are 2 minutes late or stay an extra hour. More flexibility isn't a bad thing, especially with those that have families and situations will inevitably come up.

review_title: This is a call center job. You answer customer questions concerning their policies.
job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Tulsa, OK
pros: This is a call center job. You answer customer questions concerning their medical policies.  Most people were nice but some were outright mean. This job is not for everyone.
cons: Every aspect of your day is monitored on a set amount of time and by numerous people. Calls are reviewed by many different sources. Shift, bonuses, ect.. based on performance. Break and lunches (30 min) often are different every day depending on coverage needed. If you get stuck on a call when it time to go, too bad, you stay until they are helped, which can take minutes to hours.

job_title: IT Quality Control Senior Advisor in Ames, IA

review_title: Medicaid business CCR - Lack of training, high expectations.

The main expectation is the call times to remain low and yet we weren't trained properly to reach the goals. Frustrating when you talk to your supervisor during the training process to point out that you aren't learning the hands on job training and line of business training needed but their hands are tied because of corporate.

review_title: Over 10 years of diverse experience with Anthem

- Great benefits and PTO package
- One of the largest local employers
- Stable company. Doesn't mean your job is stable, but at least you know the Company is.
cons:
- Lack of diversity in many of the departments and especially at the Director level and beyond
- Complacent attitudes toward ongoing problems 
- Layoffs and outsourcing of jobs overseas has become common and many of the Guru's have been let go
- Employees are often discouraged from asking questions. This is particularly troubling in the call center environment where employees are answering member & provider questions regarding benefits and claims
- There is often minimal training so employees are learning as they go along

review_title: If you value a work/life balance.don't apply here.

cons: Anthem does not appreciate their Customer Service employees. They expect perfection & their constantly looking for the negativity & rarely praise. You're not allowed to be human. If your sick or have an emergency come up, they consider that "unscheduled" time off and it counts against you. Ridiculous!! How about decent benefits too?

review_title: Prepare to deal with political infighting and management's lack of vision & inability to innovate.

Managers are unreasonable with their demands. Members/customers aren’t important but meeting the ‘quota’ is. It ends up being all about the numbers. Many coworkers work beyond contact hours and are not compensated in any way.  The saying is “Effort does not equal Productivity” so regardless of how hard you work it is never enough!!  Terrible upper management. They just don’t care about the employee.

job_title: Customer Care Representative in Indianapolis, IN

No structure, enforcement of rules hinders learning job, setting employee up for failure. Atmosphere and his style does 360 when mgmt walks in!

pros: From early 2000's to late 2010 was a very solid organization, good people and reasonably good focus on the core mission.   Lots of opportunities to move around and try new things.

Some positives left in many departments that are customer facing, but overall has become an awful place to work.  I began actively looking recently.

review_title: It was a decent experience however room to advance was questionable.

Steady paycheck and good pay for the position.
Good benefits.
cons: Beware of employees who always try and find what you do wrong and report it to the supervisor to try and get ahead in the dept. .When you are a new employee mistakes will happen but I always felt that certain people in the dept would report every wrong move you made causing more stress than there should have been.

job_title: Account Representative in San Francisco, CA

Stability of industry and job, interesting work, good work life balance, a good balance of travel and work outside the office 
Above average benefits package and great training opportunities, tuition assistance
Great position for networking and career learning as a young professional
cons:
Legacy systems and old business processes, efficiency and innovation is lacking
It's a large complex organization operating in different ways across segments and states, so it's often hard to find people to the job done
Few younger people in my department
Very little social interaction, it was a dead zone
No annual increase to base salary in my position, performance metrics not related to things I could actually influence

pros: Spent two decades with this company.  Pay was good.  Benefits were fine.  They had flex time as well and mgmt. didn't watch you like a hawk to ensure you were in the office at a certain time or count the minutes if you took a break.  As long as you got your work done, you were entrusted to fit it into your schedule.

Communication and teamwork between different functions isn't always the best either.  In later years, they changed benefit structures making it harder to keep some benefits you had earned.

review_title: Spent my every single lunch break crying in my car
job_title: Customer Care Representative in Columbus, GA

cons: Spending most of your calls explaining to the sick patients inquiring about their denied medical claims and basically having to explain to dying person after dying person that no their bill wasnt a mistake and having to explain to them each time  that due to an insignificant technicality in the policy wording of their benefits they are now on the hook for paying the entire amount (like $,20,000-$100,000) for having their heart attack treated by an ER doctor not in the network even though the hospital they went to was in our network. Its soul crushing work and it takes a very hard emotional toll.

review_title: Closed ENTIRE Sales Department with NO WARNING came in one day, surprise-youre all laid off. Go home.

It was ludicrous. What was an exciting and competitive place to work became drudgery.  All for someone else's profit.
cons: NO Consideration for loyal employees at all. The folks bringing in the sales were not acknowledged for their diligent and profitable work.

review_title: Continously growing to meet the needs of our members.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Roanoke, VA

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Indianapolis, IN

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Newbury Park, CA

pros: Great benefits, great pay, flexible work schedules.  We offer a product that is a necessary evil in the US society.  No one wants to get sick, but when they do they want/need health insurance.
cons: Insurance is a very regulated business.  Sometimes getting all the approvals required prior to marketing a product allows competitors to beat us to market.  There may be more negatives to report after the exchanges go into effect 1/1/2014.

job_title: Lead Customer Service Representative in Newbury Park, CA

cons: Now that Anthem has taken over, the company is more bottom line than employee satisfaction oriented.  Lay-offs were never a concern there, but now many people have lost jobs due to Anthems policy of offshoring operational type jobs offshore to cheaper and less effective workers.

pros: good pay, good benefits, good people

ROI is miscalculated for such projects more often than not. Productivity tools are cumbersome and inefficient. That limits their use, lowers the quality and increases development and testing effort.

review_title: All depends on your view and where you are

job_title: Member Retention Associate in New York, NY

cons: Unprofessional, unpolished, slave drivers. This place runs on the motto "it's not what you know, rather who you know" Preferential treatment for some. If you're interested in working like a mule and being underpaid, then this is the place for you. STAY AWAY!

job_title: PROVIDER Services in South Portland, ME

cons: . Management is less than desirable.  Things change everyday and is very confusing and overwhelming.  They will raise the level of expectation to weed out the weak and then lower it. job_title: Group Underwriter Senior in Saint Louis, MO

Work-Life balance is not good.

review_title: Information Technology Division - Managed by Fear - New Employees Beware
pros:
1. Good salaries and benefits.  
2. The written Corporate Culture and Values are inspiring and help maintain work interactions with peers at a collaborative and friendly level.
cons:
1. The company has a cut throat culture in the IT division.  Everyone is heavily overworked with demands and corporate changes causing a lack of collaboration.  The Business and IT do not collaborate well. There is a visible attitude of the business towards IT, making it clear that IT is a second or third corporate citizen.

2. IT Employees are in constant fear of loosing their jobs and since a high percentage of employees are on H1B visas, they quickly agree to work very long hours every week day/holliday and at least 8 hours most weekends. They do it because they are in fear of being placed on the cyclical Reduction-In-Force List.

3. Some Managers and Directors have grown out of H1B Visa status, their management experience is primarily with subordinates on H1B Visas and some are very rude to their subordinates while very pleasant to peers and higher levels of management.   

4. The tone that filters down from upper management is threatening. 

5. Frequent reorganization memos announcing executives being replaced and let go. 

6. All corporate changes seem to be pursued in parallel without any planning or prioritization

7. HR Policies are nice and very thoughtful. However, the HR policies are not applied consistently and in some IT departments, employees are abused by requiring to take PTO for a short family related errand or a doctor's visit even if they work in excess of 55 hours that week.  No one complains or informs HR for fear of retaliation.

8. The corporate surveys are anonymous but show the answers on a per direct manager level and it is easy for the direct manager and the 2nd level manager to identify or suspect who is the author. All employees are well aware of this fact, have known of cases of retaliation and for this reason they choose not to provide negative feedback via the surveys.

9. Rightly so, HR's policy establishes that salaries are not affected by H1B Visa status of an employee. However, some directors have their own policy of maintaining salaries of employees with H1B Visa substantially below the on going market rate.  It is difficult to detect this in cases where 90% of the direct reports are H1B visa holders. For this reason, the salary surveys, used to identify the  market rate,  should not include the salaries of H1B Visa holders and this way enabling the comparison. 
 
10. New employees in particular are vulnerable because they are given and like the policies.  However, they find the hard way that their reality is based on who is their direct boss and not on the written policies. In addition, since a new employee is not aware about rivalries among VPs, it is relatively easy to get caught in feuds. Furthermore, since very few procedures are written and the ones that are written are outdated, the new employees' primary source of knowledge is their direct Manager. If your direct manager inherits you through a reorg, then you are in their hands. You are lucky if your new manager is confident of his position, not afraid of sharing his knowledge and developing new leadership under him. If this is not the case, my advise is to lay low and be a Yes/Yes person, work 60 hours per week, never volunteer information about issues or solutions to anyone but your direct manager.  The frequent RIFs enable all the political moves your direct manager wants to make and this way ensure he is safe from future RIFs.

Zero/minimal work/life balance - people need to work at all hours to cover responsibilities and time zones. Leaders have set incredibly poor examples with their own health situations, working ungodly hours, expecting associates to work those and wearing multiple hats. Working from home can also make one work unnecessary hours. Efficiencies are lost.

Job security - very poor. This is a for profit company. When they are losing money or need to generate revenue (based on financial forecasts) for any business division, the company will enforce company wide reductions of staff. This is regardless of how high a performer you are and what solid reputation withheld in the company. If you have attained a certain salary level or number of years, you can be a target by any one division. They will state for reasons of "organizational changes" or "admin cost reductions", etc. There is zero/minimal efforts to redeploy you in a timely manner to give one a fighting chance again to reinstate one's career.
